The inferred statement "If we go to the concert and a bomb goes off, then we'll have a good time" can be represented as (P ∧ R) → Q, where R is "a bomb goes off." 

In logic, from P → Q, we cannot validly infer (P ∧ R) → Q because strengthening the antecedent (adding R) may introduce conditions that affect the truth of Q. For example, if a bomb goes off (R is true), it could plausibly make Q false (we do not have a good time) even if P is true, without contradicting the original implication. The original statement only guarantees a good time when we go to the concert under normal circumstances, but it does not account for extreme events like a bomb explosion.
